children.title: baptism
children.comment: A washing with water, which symbolises the cleansing of believers from the stain and dirt of sin through the grace of God. Jesus Christ submitted to baptism as an example to believers. Through the work of the Holy Spirit, baptism is linked with union with the risen Jesus Christ.

children.title: baptism, in the Gospels
children.comment: In the Gospels baptising is based on the symbolic practice in the OT and Judaism of cleansing with water.

children.title: Washing was the means of achieving ritual purity

secondaryrefs.comment: The Greek word here translated ``wash'' is ``baptizo'', from which the English ``baptise'' comes.

children.title: Sprinkling with water symbolises spiritual cleansing
Being baptised by John was a confession that cleansing was needed
John promised that the Messiah would cleanse with the baptism of the Holy Spirit
Baptism involves both water and the Holy Spirit
The disciples of Jesus Christ baptised like John's
Jesus Christ was baptised by John
baptism, practice of
children.comment: Baptism is associated with repenting of sin, believing the gospel message and becoming a member of Christ's body.

children.title: Baptism is ordained by Jesus Christ himself

seealsos.comment: The ``baptisms'' referred to here may imply teaching about Jewish rituals or the baptism offered by John the Baptist.

children.title: Baptism follows the decision to believe
Baptism in the name of God or Jesus Christ
Baptism in or into the name of Jesus Christ
Baptism in the name of the Trinity

primaryrefs.comment: The word ``buried'' implies immersion.

children.title: Baptism is linked with the gift of the Holy Spirit

primaryrefs.comment: All the Christians at Corinth had been spiritually baptised into Christ and thus united with him.

children.title: Manifestations of the Holy Spirit may follow or precede water baptism
The person who baptises is of little importance

primaryrefs.comment: What matters is not who baptises but the Saviour in whose name it is done.
It is not certain if there was a ceremony of baptism ``for the dead'' in the NT church, nor whether, if it existed, Paul approved of it.

children.title: Passages which may imply infant baptism
children.precomment: The ``households'' (not merely individuals) may well have included children:

secondaryrefs.comment: If baptism is here equated with circumcision, this suggests baptism is the sign of the new covenant.
Under the new covenant it is faith in Jesus Christ, not an outward sign, that makes a person a child of God.

children.title: baptism, significance of
children.comment: The NT uses a variety of images to explain the meaning of baptism, such as dying and rising with Christ, sharing in his death and being cleansed from sin.

children.title: Baptism is a symbol of the death of Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ described his death as a baptism or a flood overwhelming him.

children.title: Baptism is a symbol of the burial of Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Immersion in water symbolises how the old sinful life is buried with Christ.

children.title: Baptism is a symbol of being saved from the flood

primaryrefs.comment: The flood/baptism symbolises both judgment (the death of sinners and the death of Jesus Christ) and salvation (those in the ark and those in Christ passing safely through judgment).

children.title: Baptism is the gospel equivalent of circumcision

primaryrefs.comment: The ``circumcision in Christ'' may refer either to his death on the cross or to baptism.
In and through the exodus experience Israel was united with and obedient to Moses, as Jesus Christ's people are to him.
Baptism is an outward sign of cleansing from sin and from a defiled life and conscience.

children.title: Baptism is a symbol of putting on Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Baptism is seen as putting on Christ, as one might put on a coat or garment, and thus be ``clothed with Christ''.

children.title: Baptism as a symbol of unity
baptism, in the Gospels
children.comment: In the Gospels baptising is based on the symbolic practice in the OT and Judaism of cleansing with water.

children.title: Washing was the means of achieving ritual purity

secondaryrefs.comment: The Greek word here translated ``wash'' is ``baptizo'', from which the English ``baptise'' comes.

children.title: Baptism as a symbol of unity
collections
children.comment: The financial burden of God's work has always been shared amongst God's people. In the OT, this was mainly by compulsory tithes; in the NT by voluntary contributions.

cschildren.title: The collection of compulsory tithes and other religious taxes
The collection of voluntary contributions

children.title: For the rebuilding of the temple
For the teaching ministry of the church
For the relief of the poor

cschildren.title: The aim of collections
The right attitude to collections
The faithful administration of collections

children.title: confirmation
children.comment: The act of publicly affirming something or someone, usually with a view to declaring trustworthiness. God confirmed his covenants, oaths and promises to emphasise his intention to fulfil them and he confirms the gospel to demonstrate its truthfulness.

cschildren.title: Confirmation of covenants
Confirmation of oaths
Confirmation of promises
Confirmation of the gospel
Confirmation of wisdom
Confirmation of vows

seealsos.comment: A vow made by a woman could be either confirmed or nullified by her father or husband.

cschildren.title: Confirmation of a witness's testimony

primaryrefs.comment: Evidence accepted in court required confirmation by more than one witness.

seealsos.comment: The proper judicial procedure was not followed at the trial of Jesus Christ
Paul here invokes the Holy Spirit as a witness

cschildren.title: Confirmation of letters

primaryrefs.comment: This constituted verification of the authenticity of a letter which could easily have been forged or tampered with.

cschildren.title: Confirmation of office or position

children.title: excommunication
children.comment: The last but reversible step in church discipline, resulting in exclusion from the fellowship of believers. The grounds that Scripture suggests for excommunication include public sin and immorality.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ authorises the church to excommunicate a sinning brother

primaryrefs.comment: The binding of sinners is thought to refer to their exclusion from God's people, and loosing, to their restoration after repentance (compare Mt 16:19).

cschildren.title: Paul exhorts the Corinthian church to excommunicate an immoral brother

primaryrefs.comment: By ``hand this man over to Satan'' (see also 1Ti 1:20) Paul means to expel him, by putting him out into the devil's territory, in the hope that being officially ostracised, he might repent and forsake his wicked way. Such discipline was necessary not only for the reclaiming of the sinner but also for the safety and purity of the church (verse 6).

cschildren.title: Excommunicated offenders who repent are to be lovingly restored to fellowship

secondaryrefs.comment: This passage probably refers to the offender mentioned in 1Corinthians chapter 5.

children.title: fellowship
children.comment: Association based upon the sharing of something in common. Believers have fellowship with one another on the basis of their common fellowship with God, their participation in the blessings of the gospel and their common task of mission. True fellowship is demonstrated in concern for, and practical commitment to, one another.

children.title: fellowship, with God
children.comment: The relationship with God, disrupted by sin yet established through Jesus Christ, which provides the only proper basis for true human fellowship. God's desire for fellowship with humanity is made known through his calling of a people to be his own and to reflect his holiness and love.

children.title: God's fellowship with his people is shown by his presence
God's presence in the new Jerusalem
Fellowship with the Father, Son and Holy Spirit

seealsos.comment: fellowship with the Spirit

children.title: Fellowship is made possible through Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ's presence with his disciples
abiding in Christ
united with Christ in his death and resurrection
communion with Christ at the Lord's Supper
sharing in Christ's sufferings

children.title: Fellowship with God is inseparable from fellowship with one another
The demands of fellowship with God
Sin separates people from fellowship with God
fellowship, in the gospel
children.comment: A mutual participation in the blessings of God's grace. Believers are united with one another on the basis of their common reception of the benefits of salvation.

children.title: Fellowship and the community of God's people
God calls out a community of people, for fellowship with himself
God will bless a people united in fellowship

secondaryrefs.comment: Wrong relationships between God's people hinder the flow of his blessing.

children.title: God will restore fellowship with his scattered people

seealsos.comment: sharing in the blessings of the gospel
sharing in God's grace
sharing a common faith
sharing a common calling
sharing a common hope
sharing the divine nature
sharing in sanctification
the family prayer in which believers together address God as Father

children.title: Fellowship in holding a common truth
fellowship, in Christian service
children.comment: Partnership in a common enterprise. God's people are called to work together especially in the task of mission, to recognise one another's gifts and to give support to one another's ministries.

primaryrefs.comment: The Philippians share in Paul's work through their giving.

children.title: Fellowship between Paul and his co-workers
In fellowship different gifts are combined for effective service
Spiritual gifts are given to all to share
Examples of sharing in different roles
Examples of working together in fellowship

seealsos.comment: the Reubenites and the Gadites join with the rest of Israel to conquer Canaan
all Israel unites against Gibeah
Those returning from exile work together to rebuild the temple
The Israelites work together to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem
Peter and Andrew, James and John are business partners.

children.title: fellowship, among believers
children.comment: The fellowship that believers share as a result of their common union with God through Jesus Christ is expressed in life together. It is evident in worship together, in a love for one another which reflects God's own love and in a practical commitment to one another which is demonstrated in concern for the weak and readiness to share with the poor and needy.

children.title: Sharing in the fellowship of God's love
Sharing in the fellowship of a common devotional life

secondaryrefs.comment: Love feasts accompanied the Lord's Supper though these were open to abuse.

children.title: True fellowship means sharing with those in need

seealsos.comment: God's people are to reflect his concern for the needy in society

children.title: Examples of sharing with the needy
Strengthening one another in fellowship together
Putting the needs of others first
True fellowship means living in harmony

secondaryrefs.comment: Troublemakers in David's army are unwilling to share the spoils
factions within the church at Corinth
Selfishness at love feasts humiliates the poor.

children.title: hymn
children.comment: Poetry sung to the praise of God and for the mutual encouragement of believers. Hymns and songs are not clearly distinguished in Scripture, but the NT contains examples of possible early Christian hymns.

cschildren.title: Hymns are sung to the praise of God's name

primaryrefs.comment: Because of Jesus Christ the Gentiles are now called upon to join with God's people in praising God.

cschildren.title: Christians are to sing hymns together for mutual encouragement

seealsos.comment: ``Psalms'' refers to the OT psalms (see Lk 20:42; 24:44; Ac 1:20; 13:33) some of which may have been set to music by Christians. ``Psalm'' could also describe a song newly composed for Christian worship (see 1Co 14:26 where ``hymn'' translates Greek ``psalmos'').

cschildren.title: Examples of singing hymns

children.title: By Jesus Christ and his disciples
By Paul and Silas in prison

cschildren.title: Examples of hymns

children.title: The Benedictus: Zechariah's song of thanksgiving at the birth of his son, John the Baptist
The Magnificat: Mary's song of praise as the future mother of the Lord
The Nunc Dimittis: Simeon's response to seeing the child Jesus
Other examples of possible early Christian hymns
Lord's Day, the
children.comment: As well as keeping the Sabbath, the first Christians assembled together on the first day of the week to commemorate Jesus Christ's resurrection through the Lord's Supper. The Lord's Day quickly became the focal point of the Christian week, eventually assuming the characteristics of the Jewish Sabbath, namely worship and rest.

cschildren.title: The disciples continued to observe the Sabbath
The Lord's Day commemorated Jesus Christ's resurrection

children.title: The resurrection took place on the first day of the week
The disciples assembled together on the first day of the week

cschildren.title: The Lord's Day took over the role of the Sabbath

children.title: Lord's Supper
children.comment: The commemoration and remembrance of Jesus Christ's last supper, and all the benefits that result to believers. Other terms have been used subsequently by Christians, including ``Communion'' and ``Eucharist''.

cschildren.title: Terms for the Lord's Supper in the NT

secondaryrefs.comment: ``breaking of bread'' could mean both eating together and also celebrating the Lord's Supper
The Greek word ``koinonia'', here translated ``participation'', is traditionally translated ``communion'': hence the term ``Holy Communion''
Underlying ``had given thanks'' is the Greek ``eucharisteo'', from which comes the term ``Eucharist''.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ's institution of the Lord's Supper
Celebrating the Lord's Supper in the NT

children.title: As part of an ordinary meal

primaryrefs.comment: The church was not necessarily wrong to include the sacrament in an ordinary meal; this should have been conducted in a charitable way.

children.title: The fourfold formula for breaking bread: taking, giving thanks, breaking, giving

cschildren.title: Themes connected with the Lord's Supper

seealsos.comment: Caiaphas' words may have an unintended Passover significance

primaryrefs.comment: The reference to the (new) covenant implies a personal relationship with God and sins forgiven.
Paul is referring to feasts in heathen temples.

children.title: love feast
children.comment: The first Christians generally celebrated the Lord's Supper with the accompaniment of a meal, called the ``agape'' or ``love feast''.

cschildren.title: OT antecedents of the love feast
The NT practice of the love feast

children.title: It was linked with the Lord's Supper

seealsos.comment: It was at the Last Supper that Jesus Christ gave his new commandment to his disciples to love one another as he had loved them.

cschildren.title: Abuses of the love feast
The heavenly love feast

children.title: The marriage supper of the Lamb

seealsos.comment: The parable of the marriage supper indicates the prerequisites for attendance at the supper.

children.title: ministry
children.comment: Service of a general, as well as a religious, nature. In its broadest sense ministry refers to service rendered to God or to people. Its more restricted sense refers to the official service of individuals, specially set aside by the church.

children.title: ministry, nature of
children.comment: All creatures owe their Creator a ministry of service to him and to humanity. The example and teaching of Jesus Christ illustrate this.

children.title: All human beings owe a ministry of service to God
The debt owed by the creature to the Creator
The service of the nations and their rulers
Examples of the service of rulers
The ministry of the people of God

seealsos.comment: resurrected martyrs

children.title: The ministry of priests, kings and prophets in the OT
The ministry of those specially set aside by the church
Jesus Christ fulfils the OT understanding of ministry
His ministry as shepherd, teacher and prophet
NT ministry follows the pattern of Jesus Christ
In priesthood by self-sacrifice and intercession in prayer
Jesus Christ's servants can expect the same response that he received
The ministry of angels
children.precomment: Angels are both ministers to God's people and fellow-servants with them:

children.title: ministry, in the church
children.comment: The regular ministry of officially appointed or recognised ministers is a particular instance of the duty and call of all God's people.

children.title: The responsibilities of those in recognised ministry
What believers owe to those with recognised ministries

primaryrefs.comment: Despite Jesus Christ's command, Paul did not claim his rights in this matter, but supported himself as a tentmaker.

children.title: Recognised ministers should encourage the ministries of other believers

seealsos.comment: The Holy Spirit allocates gifts and enables ministries. No individual has all the gifts; ministry is shared and mutual

children.title: The motivation of ministry is mutual love
How love is expressed in mutual ministry
In prayer and confession of sin
ministry, qualifications for
children.comment: God, who calls his people to minister, also equips his people. The chief qualifications are a response to God's call, faithfulness, godliness and Christlikeness.

children.title: Qualification is by call, not gifting or achievement
God calls those who the world regards as weak or foolish
Feelings of inadequacy to God's call are common
Responding to God's call to minister
Faith, rather than natural talent or moral perfection, is required

seealsos.comment: Jacob was a deceiver
Moses and Aaron disobeyed God.
Solomon disobeyed God's command.

children.title: NT ministers are recognised by call rather than their achievement

secondaryrefs.comment: The Twelve, including Peter and Judas, failed Jesus Christ at critical times.
Though greatly gifted, Paul was kept humble by his sense of unworthiness, difficulties and disappointments and his ``thorn in the flesh''

children.title: Ministry in the NT is described as service
Ministry is described in terms of its source, content or nature
Various ministries are equally linked by qualifications of character

Simon was not right with God.
The replacement apostle for Judas had to have been with Jesus Christ from the beginning.

children.title: mission
children.comment: Specific actions that bear witness to the good news of what God has done for his people. Israel, Jesus Christ and the church all in their different ways bear witness to the saving acts of God in history. Christian mission is empowered by the Holy Spirit.

children.title: mission, of Israel
children.comment: God chose Israel to be his own people, and bring the good news of his salvation to the world. God's mission through Israel is fulfilled in the mission of his servant and continues through the mission of the church.

children.title: Israel as a channel of God's blessing
Blessings for all people through Abraham

seealsos.comment: God's promise repeated to Isaac
God's promise repeated to Jacob

children.title: Israel's call to be a nation of priests
God's desire to display his glory
God's glory is to fill the earth
God's people declare his glory among the nations
The nations will be drawn to God's people
In recognition of God's presence among his people
To Jerusalem as the centre of universal worship
God made known through his mighty acts
God's action on behalf of Israel
Israel as a witness to other nations
God's people sent to other nations
Examples of God's people bearing witness to him
The fulfilment of God's mission through Israel

seealsos.comment: God's promise to Abraham is fulfilled through the Messianic king

children.title: mission, of Jesus Christ
children.comment: Jesus Christ came to reveal God, to announce the coming of God's kingdom and to redeem a fallen humanity through his death on the cross. Though he came first to the Jews, the scope of Christ's mission includes the whole human race and continues through the Spirit-empowered witness of the church.

children.title: Jesus Christ's mission originated with God
Jesus Christ came in willing obedience to the Father
Jesus Christ's mission was motivated by God's love
Jesus Christ's mission was to make God known
He reveals God in his own person
He reveals God through his teaching
Jesus Christ's mission was to announce God's kingdom

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ's miracles reveal the presence of God's kingdom.

children.title: Jesus Christ's mission was to redeem humanity
He came to seek and save the lost
He came to save from sin
He came to break the devil's power
He came to bring eternal life
He came to give access to God
He came to restore a fallen humanity
Jesus Christ's mission was to establish the church
The scope of Jesus Christ's mission
Jesus Christ came first to Israel
Jesus Christ's mission extends to all peoples

Jesus Christ grants the request of a Canaanite woman
Jesus Christ sends his disciples out into the whole world

children.title: Jesus Christ's mission made the cross necessary
Jesus Christ's mission will be completed at his return
Jesus Christ's mission continues through the church
mission, of the church
children.comment: The continuation of Jesus Christ's mission through his followers. Believers are empowered by the Holy Spirit and sent out by Christ to bear witness to him and to preach, heal, teach, baptise and make disciples of all peoples.

Believers are sent out by Jesus Christ

children.comment: Jesus Christ came to reveal God, to announce the coming of God's kingdom and to redeem a fallen humanity through his death on the cross. Though he came first to the Jews, the scope of Christ's mission includes the whole human race and continues through the Spirit-empowered witness of the church.

children.title: Jesus Christ's mission originated with God
Jesus Christ came in willing obedience to the Father
Jesus Christ's mission was motivated by God's love
Jesus Christ's mission was to make God known
He reveals God in his own person
He reveals God through his teaching
Jesus Christ's mission was to announce God's kingdom

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ's miracles reveal the presence of God's kingdom.

children.title: Jesus Christ's mission was to redeem humanity
He came to seek and save the lost
He came to save from sin
He came to break the devil's power
He came to bring eternal life
He came to give access to God
He came to restore a fallen humanity
Jesus Christ's mission was to establish the church
The scope of Jesus Christ's mission
Jesus Christ came first to Israel
Jesus Christ's mission extends to all peoples

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ commends the faith of a Roman centurion
Jesus Christ grants the request of a Canaanite woman
Jesus Christ sends his disciples out into the whole world
Paul's commission to go to the Gentiles is received directly from Jesus Christ.

children.title: Jesus Christ's mission made the cross necessary
Jesus Christ's mission will be completed at his return
Jesus Christ's mission continues through the church
mission, of the church
children.comment: The continuation of Jesus Christ's mission through his followers. Believers are empowered by the Holy Spirit and sent out by Christ to bear witness to him and to preach, heal, teach, baptise and make disciples of all peoples.

children.title: The power and authority of the church's mission
Believers are sent out by Jesus Christ
Believers are given authority by Jesus Christ
Believers are empowered by the Holy Spirit
The task of the church in mission
The universal scope of the church's mission
The church reaching out in mission

primaryrefs.comment: The disiples' mission began with the Jews.

seealsos.comment: The scattered believers at first preached only to Jews.

children.title: To the Gentiles
children.precomment: Paul as the apostle to the Gentiles:

secondaryrefs.comment: Peter preaches to Cornelius and his family
Scattered believers preach to the Gentiles
Paul begins his first missionary journey (with Barnabas)
Paul begins his second missionary journey (with Silas)
Paul is called to preach the gospel in Macedonia
Paul preaches the gospel in Rome.
Barnabas is sent to Antioch to strengthen the new church.
Judas and Silas are sent to Antioch with a letter from the apostles and elders.

children.title: sacraments
children.comment: The sacraments of baptism and the Lord's Supper were instituted by Jesus Christ as signs and seals of the covenant.  They explain the basis of this covenant and apply its benefits to believers.  They replace circumcision and the Passover which were the sacraments of the old covenant.

cschildren.title: The sacraments as signs of the new covenant

primaryrefs.comment: Baptism is one sign of being a disciple of Jesus Christ.
The new covenant was sealed by the blood of Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: The sacraments as a participation in the body of Christ

primaryrefs.comment: In the NT baptism immediately follows conversion and testifies to the individual's union with Christ.
The ``body of Christ'' is a term which goes beyond Jesus Christ to the church. Those who partake of the bread in this way are declaring their membership of the church.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ likens himself to bread as he is the source of spiritual life and nourishment
The believer who eats the bread of the Lord's Supper is renewing his or her dependence on Jesus Christ for spiritual life.

cschildren.title: The sacraments as a participation in the death of Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Through baptism individuals declare that they have applied to themselves the death of Jesus Christ which atones for sin.

seealsos.comment: Baptism does not accomplish the cleansing from sin but it is the outward sign that this has taken place by faith

primaryrefs.comment: In taking the emblems of Jesus Christ's broken body and shed blood individuals perpetually apply the merits of Christ's death (i.e., forgiveness of sins) to themselves.

cschildren.title: The sacraments of the old covenant

primaryrefs.comment: Circumcision was the initiation rite under the old covenant.

seealsos.comment: Circumcision was never meant as merely an outward rite. To be effective it required a right attitude of heart
Circumcision was the seal of Abraham's righteousness imputed to him by his faith
Circumcision has now been superseded by baptism for the Christian as the rite of initiation.

primaryrefs.comment: The Passover meal was instituted as a regular commemoration of Israel's redemption from slavery in Egypt.

seealsos.comment: The death of Jesus Christ is closely associated with the Passover by its timing and meaning. The Lord's Supper has superseded the Passover as the corporate meal commemorating the act of redemption

children.title: singing
children.comment: The musical voicing of praise to God. On account of God's majesty and great acts of salvation singing was a regular part of the life of Israel and of the early church. In Israel musicians and singers were set aside solely for this purpose.

cschildren.title: The call to sing praise to God
The resolve to sing praise to God
Singing in response to God's deliverance from enemies and sin
God sings of his delight and love for his people
Singing in Israel

seealsos.comment: the bringing of the ark to Jerusalem
the dedication of the temple
a march into battle
a coronation
the purification of the temple
the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem

children.title: Musicians and singers appointed to lead Israel's singing

cschildren.title: Singing in the NT
Singing is not always appropriate

primaryrefs.comment: God detests the songs of Israel that are not accompanied by obedience and justice.

children.title: song
children.comment: In Scripture, songs express praise, thanksgiving, joy, victory and love. They also express sadness and derision and can be used to teach and warn. In heaven believers will sing a new song to God.

cschildren.title: Different kinds of song

primaryrefs.comment: The song celebrating God's spectacular victory over Pharaoh and his army (compare with Rev 15:3).
``psalms, hymns and spiritual songs'' are not clearly distinguished from each other in Scripture.

secondaryrefs.comment: Psalms 120-134, the so-called ``Songs of Ascent'', are thought to have been sung by pilgrims on their way to Jerusalem.
The title to this psalm describes it as ``a wedding song''

seealsos.comment: The book of Lamentations is a series of laments after the fall of Jerusalem

cschildren.title: God is described as the song of believers
Songs can teach and warn
A new song

children.title: Singing a new song to God expresses a renewed desire to praise him
In heaven God's people will sing a new song
spiritual gifts
children.comment: Although all believers have received the gift of the Holy Spirit, Scripture points to God giving individuals certain special gifts of a spiritual nature for the fulfilling of specific tasks.

children.title: spiritual gifts, and responsibility
children.comment: A spiritual gift may be intended to equip its recipient for a specific function or appointment. Those who are equipped in this way need the enabling power of God's spirit to carry out their appointed tasks.

children.title: OT examples of God's gifts or appointments
God appoints the Persian king Cyrus
God empowers leaders and kings with his Spirit
The Spirit is given to the servant of the LORD
Jesus Christ is endowed with the Holy Spirit
The apostles are endowed with the Holy Spirit
Spiritual gifts given to the church
Many functions within the church yet unity is preserved
All Christians are appointed to build up the church
Associated with the laying on of hands
Spiritual gifts must not to be neglected
spiritual gifts, nature of
children.comment: In both the OT and the NT God graciously pours out gifts on his people. They are to be welcomed and used for the good of all.

children.title: OT examples of God giving special gifts

primaryrefs.comment: This gracious provision of material needs from above can be seen as foreshadowing God's bestowal of spiritual gifts.
The Hebrew word for ``give'' often includes the sense of ``apportion'' or ``assign''.

children.title: The future promise of spiritual gifts
In his earthly ministry Jesus Christ offers supernatural gifts
The purpose of spiritual gifts is to build up the church
The body of Christ benefits from these varied gifts
Encouragement to aspire to the greater spiritual gifts
The importance of love in exercising spiritual gifts

tongues, gift of
children.comment: The divine enabling of a believer to use a language, unknown to the speaker. The gift of tongues may be used to praise God or to utter a message from God that, supplemented by the gift of interpretation of tongues, edifies other believers. Note that ``tongues'' can simply mean ``other languages'' at times.

cschildren.title: Tongues is a gift of the Holy Spirit

children.title: It is given to individual believers

seealsos.comment: it is not universal among Christians

children.title: It was foretold in the OT
It is a divine gift in response to faith
It may be given through the laying on of hands
It is a sign of the presence of the Holy Spirit

cschildren.title: Tongues in relation to other gifts
The use of tongues within the church

children.title: In public it needs to be augmented by the gift of interpretation
